div.p: Greetings. Reverend Father in Christ, although there is nothing at all to write, for I have not heard anything from friends, whom I am certain are not idle, nevertheless, since Nicolaus from the Pellizari family was traveling to Frankfurt, I wanted him to visit you on the occasion of my letters. If you wanted to write to friends, you would have someone to whom you could give the letters.

As for our affairs, everything is complicated, and I am struggling with the greatest difficulties and I begin to foresee that whether an alliance is made or refused, we will be in a precarious situation.

But our lords have hurried and set articles; if King Philipp accepts, then ours can come to an agreement; for I think that much money has been spent on it and the preparations have already been made. What do you want me to say? I do not dare to entrust to letters what I wish.
Oh, if only I could pour my heart into your bosom! I do not fear Philipp, but our own sins.

If I oppose it vehemently, then the preparations have already been made. If it is rejected, then Philipp threatens war; then we priests are to blame, and people will come into the country against each other. I cannot advise it either; for the matter seems suspicious to me, even if good words are given.

May God have mercy on us and not give us according to our deserts! I do not dare to write more, although I would very much like to. Hercules from Salicibus is pressing the matter and promises many good things, especially regarding religion; others do not believe everything he says. Farewell, reverend Father in Christ, and inform us about the affairs in France and Germany.
As for the main issue, I always stand firm; as for the circumstances, they vary so much from day to day and hour to hour that the plan must be changed daily. Something new comes up every day.

In short, there is nothing complete from top to bottom; therefore, our matter cannot have much stability, etc. To the most distinguished man, Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and honorable Father in Christ.
